author: encryptiondk63
title: Left without a social prescriber and the stair lift they were arranging
body:
Our social prescriber managed to get 2 Charities to provide a stair left however sadly without warning we received a letter saying she was no longer wasn't assigned to the person I care for.. We still haven't got a stair lift due to no socket at top of stairs. Council won't fit a socket nor social services so again we're back to square one.  
We didn't know our social prescriber wasn't permanent and really would have appreciated being more informed. It's very difficult going to work and coming home looking after someone. All w ever asked for is to have some benefits help so I can afford to lessen my hours therefore enabling me to have more time to be a carer. To be honest I feel very let down and still we are no further forward with the stair lift.

author: Karl 1
title: Great Experience in ED
body:
I attended ED at 2am and was treated with kindness and care. Although there were delays with updates about what was happening, this was minor and still things were progressed as swiftly as they could.  
Just a couple of things, twice during my stay I was offered a blanket, but these never were delivered. Although I could have asked.  
I had lots of updates towards the end of my stay and I left knowing exactly what I needed to do and what would happen next.  
I was grateful to the efficiency of phlebotomy who turned around my bloods as swiftly as possible. Also thanks to the Radiographer who performed my chest X-ray.  
Thanks as well to the nurses and doctors responsible for my care.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: timbo01
title: My skin cancer
body:
Ok not life threatening thankfully but very worrying as it was on my face , I would just like to express my thanks to the dermatology team , I have been very lucky in life at the age of 58 I have never had to to go hospital for anything like this surgery, However, I have worked all my life and never been unemployed so I have paid into the nhs without ever using it.  
My point is I have now seen 1st hand how my taxes have been spent , I can not remember the doctor/surgeon name but they were so very professional, calming, reassuring, and I was totally at ease - money well spent!!  
So a massive thanks to the doctor/ surgeon and her team!!  
All heroes!

author: travellerrd67
title: The care had excellent results
body: The care I had from the 3 ladies who visited me - Jolene, Allie & Julie - was first class. I would not have progressed as well without their care. The exercises given to me had excellent results ( I did them regularly) and I was visited twice or three times a week to keep check on me. My walking has progressed so well that I can walk further each week. Julie came specially to walk with me until I was discharged 2 weeks ago. My goal was reached before discharge and is surpassed greatly now. My hand was soon useful again due to the 'grasp' exercises and is now fully operational. My grateful thanks to all 3 ladies who cared.

author: fornaxwh48
title: Gave the tools to cope
body:
I was feeling down and was sick and tired of feeling this way.  
STARS helped with my problem. And gave the tools to cope better than I was.

author: MummyT01
title: Health Visiting Service
body:
I'm really not one to complain, but I find the health visitor service at the minute is absolutely appalling. My daughter has not been seen by a health visitor since she was 4 months old and she's now 18 months.  
I received a couple of letters in the post, explaining milestones she should be reaching and if I remember correctly, the letter I received around 6 months of age advised I should be weaning off bottles of formula. Zero mention of breastfeeding. Not very inclusive to myself as a breastfeeding mother that no advise was offered.  
It was down to me to recognise problems with my daughter. When I did, I called my health visitor and to be honest - I felt that they didn't really care. Advised me to visit my GP which was fine but never asked how my child was getting on otherwise. This problem in particular may have been something a health visitor could of picked up as looking back, I can see subtle signs of her condition that I wasn't aware of. I received one follow up phone call from my health visitor a few months later and they had no idea my child had been through 2 surgeries and offered no advice on it. I haven't heard from the health visitor since!  
As a first time mum, I find the service unacceptable.  
A simple phone call here and there would not go amiss - especially when it comes to the development of a child and the mental wellbeing of a parent!  
Hopefully it will improve soon.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: msbpolak
title: Super team
body: I wanted to write to thank the super team who supported me in my recent gynecology appointment.   I could not have had a warmer or more supportive appointment.   From start to finish the staff on the unit department were kind and welcoming, each and every one of them and once I got into my consultant room the consultant was absolutely brilliant.. super relaxed, informative and upbeat which was exactly what I needed.   It's extraordinary to me how the department can keep their spirits up in such challenging times and I will be forever grateful.

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

author: J7
title: Complacent with newcomers
body:
I feel that some of the staff are complacent with newcomers in the holding cell and presume introduction is not important. I was left believing the door was locked, and for an hour I knocked calling out that I needed to use the toilet.  
Eventually the member of staff shouted through that the door was open and turn away without showing me where the toilet was!  
There was also another member of staff member who wore no mask while pushing me back into my bedroom at 6 am, telling me I was up too early, literally in my face.

author: TuesdayJ
title: Appointment in ultrasound
body: Through out the pandemic, I‚Äôve become more nervous and have developed anxiety issues. I was worried about entering the hospital and quickly rushed to the ultrasound reception, once I got there the lady on reception was wonderful! From the moment she opened her mouth to greet me, I felt at ease! She made me feel comfortable and that‚Äôs exactly what I needed! She spoke to me about my name and we had a small chat, no one else was waiting so not to disturb anyone else! The other male that was on the desk (Saviour) was also very welcoming and spoke nicely towards me! I was very impressed with the customer service that I received!

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: hotelzx59
title: Very comfortable
body: My first time getting my infusion therapy has been a great success. Everything well and staff all great. The ward was very comfortable and the food was delicious and much appreciated.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: doradoqc47
title: The clinic runs like clockwork
body:
I attend the Day Clinical Centre at South Tyrone Hospital to receive my biological treatment for my rheumatoid arthritis.  
I prefer coming to this hospital as I feel safer and the procedures and practices the staff have in operation in South Tyrone are brilliant, and the clinic runs like clockwork.  
The staff to me, seem happier, more content while they are working as they are safer at this clinic at South Tyrone.  
The staff always make me feel at ease and make the day go as smoothly as possible.  
Although there are services closer to me, I would be more than happy to continue to travel to South Tyrone to receive my treatment.  
All the staff members are very good and what they have been trained and their bedside manner is second to none, in particular Robert at the clinic he is brilliant at his job. They need recognised for the job they do.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kindness123
title: Outpatient scan appointment
body:
I care for my mother with Dementia and try to always do what I think she would want I don‚Äôt always know what is right and have no idea if she is happy or not. I visited the medical physics department at Western General Hospital Edinburgh to take her for a bone density scan. Knowing my mums limitations and the help she requires I offered to get her onto the table and position her ready for the scan I also asked the radiographer to call me when she was done to allow me to help her back off the table. I do this on a daily basis in regards to moving and handling of my mother.  
As I was settling my mum in her wheelchair the radiographer placed her hand on my shoulder and said "You are very good to your mum". The genuine kindness this member of staff showed me in that small gesture was huge to me, it confirmed what I do everyday matters, even though my mum is unaware. Thank you Janice, you made my day.

author: Flower10
title: Breaking my wrist
body: I fell when I was roller skating with my friends at the park and my wrist was very sore. My friend went and got my mum and dad. I felt sore and sad. My mum took me to Arbroath Infirmary minor injury unit. The nurse was very nice and listened to my story, she decided I needed an X-ray to see if it was broken. When I went to the X-ray, I was a bit scared as it was quite dark and my mum had to wait outside. But there was a nice lady and a boy who was a student and he was very nice and he told me what to do. The nurse then phoned the orthopaedic doctors to see if I needed to go to the big hospital. They decided I just needed a splint and I got to go back home. I was a bit sad that I had to stay off school. I got a notebook with stickers and pens from the nurse which was very nice.

author: New Mum December
title: Speedy birth and aftercare
body: In the very early hours of Thursday morning I attended the BGH where my baby boy was delivered in a big hurry in A& E. While this was a scary experience for me, the staff were phenomenal and took excellent control of the situation. We were then transferred up to the Labour Ward where we were brilliantly cared for. We would especially like to thank midwife Helena for looking after us so well, and all the A& E staff involved for helping us through. We are so lucky to live in the Borders.

title: X-Ray Department
body: I had to have a Chest X-Ray this month and I must say even under the present restrictions due to COVID 19 my experience from how helpful they where at the main reception to the fully professional, well organised and helpful X-Ray department was excellent. I am lucky enough to not to have had to visit hospital very often and so had to ask for assistance from the main reception where they were both very helpful and professional. The X-Ray department dealt with me so promptly and with such professionalism, very impressed with the service I received from the NHS. 5 Star...üëèüëè

readBy.name: Plymouth University Urgent and Emergency Care Bsc (2020)

author: Lone Cyclist
title: Bad day made good
body:
Hi, taken in with very bad pain in the nether regions, from the word go I was royally looked after, given pain relief and ultimately fixed up. The nursing staff from the wards I was in were excellent and cheerful which is great when you're not feeling well!.  
So from the front door Porters to surgeons first class service with a smile which believe makes you feel upbeat in what can be scary circumstances and wondering what's going to happen.  
No names but the people know who they are.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Grateful vaccine recipient
title: The service was flexible
body: My second Covid vaccination was due at the end of May. However my husband was getting out of hospital after a 4 week stay and I didn't want to leave him alone for the length of time it would take for me to travel and get the vaccination. So I went a week early, and explained my circumstances. Everyone I met was SO lovely and understanding from the initial welcome right through to the nurse in charge.... The service was flexible enough to meet my need and on this occasion vaccinate me a week early. I was and remain very grateful. I'm just sorry I didn't think to get the names of these 'Angels of Understanding'.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: charliejf73
title: COVID-19 Vaccine
body: Excellent service from friendly staff. Very efficient and well organised!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Smevident
title: Straightforward
body: It was really straightforward, no waiting about the staff and nurses where really friendly and it was a very clean very well distanced environment.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Lou06
title: Smooth operation
body: Everything was clearly signed posted and staff where very helpful and clear in instructions. Very smooth operation and the staff were very helpful and made me feel very at ease and relaxed.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Clarem1234
title: Vaccination
body: I had my first dose of the COVID vaccine today at the Craigavon centre. The process was seamless and very easy. All of the employees and volunteers were so professional and capable it put me totally at ease. I was checked in and sitting in front of my nurse for the vaccine in less than 5 minute. My nurse, Aveen, was so friendly and helpful. She prepared me for the whole experience and explained everything. She gave me the vaccine and made sure I was all sorted for my second dose. I couldn‚Äôt have asked for a more pleasant experience!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Blobbyman
title: Covid swabbing
body: Covid test delivered well in advance. Nice not have to trek to hospital to have done. Instructions easy to follow, just read letter. No problems doing test in thoat and nose by self at home. Minor discomfort. Felt alright afterwards. Easy to package and to take where had to be left in my local area

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: BMB
title: Covid vaccine
body: Great setup for the Covid vaccine. Very friendly staff.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: omegahs35
title: Vaccination
body: Received vaccination in Foyle  Arena I was very impressed one smooth operation. Well done folksüò∑

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: errandgb78
title: Vaccine
body: It was great, the staff are all legends, really helpful

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: neptunenf87
title: Contraception
body:
I have the contraception chip in my arm, and my surgery does not change them. Therefore I needed to get it changed and came here.
The two nurse's I had were absolutely brilliant, really caring and very quick.

author: StuartL21
title: Outstanding treatment
body: Our 6 year old son hit his head on a door and got a nasty cut, which either needed Glued or stitches. We took him to Royal Hospital for Children A& E. the treatment he got from the Doctor Jonathon and the nurse Debbie was outstanding. They really put my son at ease while treating his sore cut.

author: AJCx
title: Staff put me at ease
body: I had an appointment on saturday and was greeted by a lovely lady from york and a lovely doctor. They both made me feel relaxed and had a great laugh with them. Thank you for putting me at ease.

author: jazzbb73
title: Sexual health services
body: Staff at sexual health Fife went above and beyond for me, even managing to squeeze me in for a face to face consultation despite their limited consultations being fully booked until July. Both nurses I spoke with were very kind, thorough and personable, making the process so much easier. I have sincere gratitude for their services, and would like to recommend that the number of clinics/consultations is increased. While Covid concerns are very real, as is the increased time needed for additional cleaning, there is a clear demand for services in this area as shown by the fact that appointments are severely limited until July. I was incredibly lucky to be seen so quickly and can only hope that others are able to receive the same level of care, especially in an area with such a sensitive nature.

author: weehoosie
title: The arrival of our daughter
body: I had a planned c section due to having a placenta previa in February 2021. I was first to be seen the day. The surgical team (wish I could remember their names! ) & Dr Crichton were all amazing. I felt safe and well looked after in their hands. They were all so lovely to myself and my partner and couldn‚Äôt have taken better care of us. Everything went fantastically well with the safe arrival of our daughter - we decided to give her middle name after Dr Crichton - she was our consultant throughout and we couldn‚Äôt have asked for better care.

author: castorbq69
title: Great Service
body: Hey guys, I just had my Pfizer vaccine and just wanted you to know that your staff were all amazing, super efficient, very friendly, all round fantastic experience. Great job, well done!

author: cetusmb79
title: Very grateful
body:
My Nan had an appointment for routine treatment however was noted to be wheezy. A support nurse was very discreet allowing me to speak to staff outwith earshot if my Nan. A staff nurse was also very good doing a ‚Äúcheck‚Äù on my Nan and encouraging her to seek medical help, which my Nan had not accepted when I suggested it.  
This has since led to a hospital admission for treatment.  
Very grateful to staff on shift for being both discreet, helpful and professional.

author: rainby
title: Getting my second dose of the covid vaccine
body:
I went to get my second dose of the vaccine on Sunday 16th May at the Fiona Elcock Vaccination Centre in Elgin. I had phoned the Grampian NHS line beforehand, as I am autistic, have ADHD, and a physical disability. That call itself was very long, as the call handler hadn't dealt with anything like my inquiry before. I was told to go to the front of the queue (due to ADHD and physical pain meaning I can't stand and wait), and that there would be the quiet space I requested, as I was driving.  
The person managing the queue tried to send me to the back of it twice. I had to insist I had been told to go to the front. My sunflower lanyard was visible the whole time. It was only when I pulled on it to emphasise it that they relented. It was humiliating having to pretty much argue with them in front of an extremely long queue.  
Inside, a nurse did seem to supervise me, but there was nowhere for me to sit. I was left standing for a few minutes while they worked out what to do with me. Again, skipping the queue made me feel embarrassed. There was no quiet space. I was taken round to a cubicle and the nurse was told that I was 'anxious' which was just so incorrect. No one had bothered to ask me anything.  
There was no quiet space. I had the option of waiting in the main hall (which I wish I'd done now), or going to what they said was a quiet place. It was a waiting area a door along, and it was not quiet, it was noisy with conversations that were clear and echoed. I was in pain, but also so embarrassed, ashamed, humiliated, uneasy, on edge and frightened. I was still feeling like this after 10 minutes, I wasn't in the least bit comfortable, I didn't feel looked after or supported, there was no one keeping an eye on me or even saying anything nice or reassuring, and the experience was just so unbearably distressing and upsetting I'm really glad it was my second dose. For my first, there was hardly anyone there and my dad drove for me. I wish I'd stayed in the main hall because at least the nurse there seemed really nice and the sounds were all merged together into one distressing mess rather than being a few very sharp, painfully loud conversation.  
The vaccination centre was way too busy and loud, and there was clearly absolutely no provision in place for autistic people, the staff didn't seem to know what to do with me, and physically I was uncomfortable too with all the standing (it wasn't for long by anyone else's standards, but I have nerve pain in my foot, and sacroiliitis.  
As a result of how shaken I was, I couldn't drive myself home afterwards. My mother had to drive me home.  
The whole experience was upsetting and humiliating.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: PICC line user
title: District nursing visits
body: A District nurse is supposed to come 3 out of every four Fridays to change Picc line dressing and flush. No one had come by 3pm so phoned to find out what was happening. Was told I wasn't on that day's list, as someone had changed frequency to fortnightly instead of weekly. They said they would phone back once spoken to nurses. They called back to say would come Sunday. I'd already explained I was going away, so reiterated that Sunday was no good, it should be today. They said they would speak to them again. After an hour no one had called back, so I phoned again. I was on hold for over 30 minutes. Eventually someone answered and after checking said that it had been booked in for Saturday. Why had no-one phoned me to tell me, instead of leaving me waiting and worrying about what was happening late on a Friday afternoon? This isn't the first problem I've had, one week they turned up a day early, without advising me in advance. Luckily I was in so it wasn't a problem. However I find the communication generally poor and the service disorganised as they don't seem to understand they need to come every Friday for 3 out of 4 weeks, and on the 4th week the hospital will change the dressing when I am being treated.

author: Stubbs
title: Getting back to work after being unemployed due to mental health & chronic pain
body:
After receiving psychiatric treatment for various mental health issues for many years I've ended up at the psychiatric team at Millbrook Mental health unit. From this team I have been referred onto the team at Futures Positive Individual Placement and Support Employment Services. They played a pivotal role in helping me get back to work after being unemployed for nearly 20 years.  
With the help of Younis and Sangita's weekly coaching calls I learnt valuable skills which enabled me to sail through my first interview. I not only received support leading up to this interview but also on the day, as Sangita attended it with me. With their support I managed to gain a position within the NHS.  
Once I started working I still received ongoing support from Younis and Sangita as they checked on a regular basis how I'm coping with my new role. After a few months cleaning on wards and interacting with mental health patients, I realised that I have the ability and desire to understand and help these patients with their issues. I frequently had situations where patients openly discussed their problems and fears with me and that made me feel like I made a difference in some of their lives. I approached Younis about my desire to progress into a role where I can support patients who's suffered with mental issues like myself. Younis has since helped me look for suitable roles in this field and with his support I have now been employed in a role of Health Care Assistant with the option to become a Peer Support Worker.  
I can not express how thankful I am for all the support I have received from both Younis and Sangita and I can truly recommend the services of Futures Positive Individual Placement and Services to anybody who has been unemployed due to mental health issues.

title: Good, all round support
body: Wanted to thank the practice for the continuing support I am receiving regarding a complex,  difficult to cope with condition. Administration staff, receptionists, triage team, nurses and my long suffering doctor have all worked together to help me. I do not feel that I have to apologise for the anxiety the longevity of this illness has caused because they seem to understand and cater for me when they can. Thank you so much. I hope that one day this will get better. Your support is invaluable to me and my family.

title: Terrible phone service
body:
It's very, very difficult to reach this practice - they have just one phone line. You'll waste a lot of time ringing them back.

Twice in a row they've failed to order my repeat prescription within a week of requesting it. I had to chase it up both times.

author: Fatiguewarrior
title: Managing fatigue post covid-19 infection
body:
After many months of ongoing symptoms from my initial Covid-19 infection, with fatigue being the main symptom I was referred to occupational health via my GP practice to help me try and manage my fatigue better. Having had many conversations with Sara over the last few months I feel I am getting better at managing my fatigue. Sara has helped me in understanding more about planning, pacing and prioritising daily tasks. She has provided me with more knowledge about tasks that can impact my fatigue which I previously would not have considered. She has listened and valued everything I have had to discuss and has been truly understanding which is amazing when at times you feel so alone. The service has been really beneficial as I continue to recover and manage my fatigue better.  
A special ‚ÄòThank you‚Äô to Sara for all your help and support over the last few months, I really appreciate it.

author: Aloysious
title: Professional & compassionate
body:
One afternoon in May, I dialled 999 and asked for Ambulance services.  
A crew from Livingston arrived early evening - names I remember were Ryan, Melanie, and Jackie (I think). Watching them work as a team was so reassuring; brilliant communication between them, ultra professional, and hugely compassionate but firm.  
They reached a point where they invited me to consider going to A&E. They allowed me to take time to make a decision which was to go to A&E at Forth Valley Royal where it was discovered that my troponin levels were hugely and dangerously elevated. I was admitted. Had it not been for the professionalism of Ryan and the team, by now I may have been in a very different situation. I cannot praise them highly enough and hope my gratitude can be conveyed to them.

author: Aloysious
title: First class treatment
body:
I was taken by ambulance to A&E FVRH Monday 24th. Was quickly told that blood tests showed I was having a heart attack albeit mild. All staff involved were excellent.  
Moved to an Assessment Ward (2) - kept busy with lots of tests and monitoring and again the staff were efficient, effective, and very caring - despite being rushed off their feet. I find it odd that service about health is run with little regard for the health of its staff.  
Moved to a small coronary ward; again the same high level of attention, staff highly personable and also rushed off their feet. Lots of things being put in place for me so many visits from different departments.  
The meal selection was good and the service staff really kind and helpful.  
But oh, your WiFi - three days staff tried to get me connected. It was like this two years ago when I was in FVRH and clearly, nothing has been done because anyone I spoke to complained about it. In this modern era, this has many negative impacts on a person's health. The IT department seems totally disinterested.  
I wish I could remember names but my mind is not what it was. So I'll just say a big thank you to all of you for your generosity of spirit, kindness, and attention to detail.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: cyclonetb97
title: The kindness and support of nurses
body: I awaited heart surgery. I attended pre assessment and was overwhelmed by everything despite the staff being kind and understanding. I contacted my surgeons secretary asking if surgeon could call me again as I didn't know how I would cope after surgery. Instead I received a call from Lindsay the nurse specialist, she explained everything too me but more importantly she listened to me. When I was admitted she came to see me on the ward simply to say hi and offer a friendly voice at a time I was allowed no visitors. I immediately felt at ease. When I went to surgery the staff picked me up on trolley and we had a laugh. I cannot thank all the staff at the golden jubilee enough. The staff cannot do enough for you and are so under appreciated. Thank you all for gifting me my life back.

author: Mum35
title: Mums care
body:
In April my mum was admitted to mater hospital ward c with a chest infection. The consultant updated us on a regular basis & whilst she was there a girl from the patient experience initiative sat with her and had a chat and was willing to get her anything she needed. The nursing staff where fantastic, when mum took a turn for the worse and deteriorated they allowed my sister and I to take turns to go in and see her. Sadly our my passed away but due to the compassion of the ward staff my sister & I were with her at the end , I can honestly say our mum got the best care possible and was shown dignity & respect at all times.  
My sister and I are so grateful we were able to be with our mum at the end when so many people did not get to be with there loved ones this past year

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: heronkz57
title: Excellent care
body: I came to Stobhill Hospital for an appointment after I got some bleeding between periods. I had an examination which was a bit uncomfortable but the doctor was great (she talked through what she was doing and why) and the nurse Nikki was lovely - I think she recognised it can be an uncomfortable examination and put her hand on my shoulder to comfort me. Excellent care!

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Rudy
title: Nursing care.
body:
I found it difficult to know the difference between the nursing grades as it was difficult to see their badges, so I didn't know if I was speaking to a member of trained staff. In my opinion I saw some badly fitting uniforms, which must have been very uncomfortable to work in.  
Medical staff were excellent, and always said who they were.  
On my morning of admission I was shown which bed was mine, and then left to sit there for more than 90mins, during which time no one came near me and I was completely ignored by all staff. At this point I was seriously thinking of phoning my husband to take me home.  
I'm sorry to complain, but having been a nurse many years ago I do feel that some standards have slipped when it comes to patient care.

author: Frustrated Filly
title: Day Case Surgery Waiting Times
body:
Going by other recent posts I have read on here, my guess is that this may not be read or provided with an answer but here goes!  
I was due to have a day case operation done shortly after the pandemic hit last year in 2020 as part of some breast cancer reconstruction. This was cancelled and rightly so and I was told that Ward GC had been turned into the Covid 24 hour admission screening ward. My Surgeon was very honest about the situation and appeared as equally frustrated as I am even a year later when he informed me that things were still no further on. This complaint is in no way aimed at the clinical team and more at management.  
Can you tell me what provisions NHS Highland are putting in place with regards to remobilization of all days case surgeries and when this ward will go back to being a surgical ward to allow day case surgeries to resume? Is the hospital management looking at relocating the Covid ward to another part of the hospital or using another ward for day case procedures now that other hospitals have resumed day case surgeries again? I believe the new Elective Treatment Centre currently under construction at the UHI Campus is being built to focus on Orthopedics and Eyes procedures so what will happen for other specialties? Waiting lists are continually growing and well as patient's frustrations with the lack of communication from NHS Highland!  
[Very unhappy with 'Waiting time']

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: crf07
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: HIV stigma at GP surgery
body:
I attended my GP surgery at the recommendation of my HIV consultant because he was concerned I may be pre-diabetic. I was then advised that the GP surgery would need to take blood samples from me to run some more tests. However, when I was handed the paperwork related to this blood test by the nurse, I noticed that there was a large yellow sticker on it which said ‚ÄòDANGER OF INFECTION‚Äô, on top of which the nurse was going to write ‚ÄòHIV positive‚Äô. I asked why they needed to do this and was told it was so the nurse taking my blood would be aware that they should be careful with my blood.  
As you can imagine, this was very upsetting for me ‚Äì this is very stigmatising behaviour on the part of my GP surgery and shows a lack of understanding of HIV, and of how to work with people living with HIV. I was so upset that I didn‚Äôt go through with giving a blood test and considered disengaging from NHS services altogether, including for my HIV care, because I was so shocked that I had been treated this way. I feel my GP surgery needs to receive training on working with people living with HIV so that they stop this practice immediately, and no one else is made to feel like I felt that day.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Pedro300
title: Myself and my alcohol addiction
body:
After many years of ucing alcohol as a coping mechinisim I have recently sought help with CGL at Wisbech prior to this I was unaware of their existance of CGL. I have engaged with their service just over a year ago and have found this help so very helpful; and positive. It really gives you an idea about how you can change your life for the better and I am learning various coping skills from the team to maintain my sobriety and avoid returning to my previous habits.  
I must say that the whole team here at CGL Wisbech are an amazing group. They show an amazing empathy to the members of the group in sessions they are so non judgemental and understanding of the difficulties that we are going through.  
Attending the group sessions is so positive and productive. I would just like to mention a few members of the team that I have engaged with , this is Adrian , Andrea. Mark. Steve and last but not least Nurse Michelle . These staff members have been extremely helpful in many ways and showed a fantastic level of professionalism with their care and support.

author: VicL
title: slick operation
body: Great slick operation today getting my first vaccine - huge credit to the volunteers everyone was incredibly helpful and efficient

author: xrayfx75
title: Vaccine was a well organised process
body:
Fast, efficient and well organised process.
Staff extremely friendly and helpful.
Thanks!

author: LuceWes
title: I got vaccinated!
body: What an incredibly well run and well organised set up they have at the John Scott Vaccination Centre. The staff are happy and friendly and made the experience not only seamless but throughly enjoyable! A testament to the passion and commitment of nhs workers and volunteers.

author: Gideon Bell
title: Covid 19 vaccine barnstaple leisure centre
body: All went well and very organized and friendly

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Bella1
title: Managing pain/anxiety - Primary Care Occupational Therapy
body:
I was referred to Occupational Therapy by my Doctor to help me manage my pain/stress and anxiety brought on by Fibromyalgia.  
Katrina was really lovely and she provided me with Paperwork, booklets and tips on what to do with regards to relaxation and breathing exercises to help me. I spoke with Kat for around 6 weeks and was very happy with the service I received. Although I never met with Katrina face to face, Katrina was very empathetic to my situation and I felt that she really understood what I was going through.  
I am still using some of the tips that Katrina gave to me and the breathing exercises to manage my overthinking. I don‚Äôt think Katrina could have done much more for me and I would give Katrina 10/10 for her service. I felt that Katrina really cares for you and even though my sessions all took place over the phone, it was all still very personal to me and was helped along by Katrina's calm and caring personality.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: funnycp85
title: Yoga session
body:
It was a lovely session, I was able to keep up so that made me feel good, as I haven't done much yoga for the past two years.
Made me feel better for the rest of the day, looking forward to the next session.
Thank you Jennie and everyone who helped organise.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Annyd37
title: Breast Cancer Service
body: I attended an appointment today at the Breast clinic and I feel we are privileged to have access to such a service. After referral made by my GP, I was promptly offered a cancellation appointment today. Every single aspect of the service from Admin staff, Assistant staff, Medical and Radiography staff was exemplary. Thank you to you all - you really are a credit to the Health service and we are very lucky to have you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: lauper
title: staying clean
body: i am a 55 year old male who has been using since 12, 14 year old,started glue sniffing smoking weed alcohol soon progressed to speed amphetamines injected for about 20 years until veins collapsed, suffers serious mental health issues had a broken body from various drug related incidents. gave up the speed and got myself a heroin addiction wHich i suffered with until 2020 came to CGL WISBECH and met dr mandizvidzg who was very kind very helpful prescribing pyseptone and being very supportive as are all the staff at Wisbech branch.who i owe thanks to help keep me clean for the last ten months and counting thank you all

author: doradokh87
title: My recovery on the ward
body: I had constant mood changes cycling up and down very fast, I was feeling very exhausted. I join in with the peer advocate meetings every Wednesday Martin and Kerry Anne have helped me with being informed of options when I'm out to continue my heeling like the recovery college, it's made me feel better that I'm not just going to be left alone when I'm discharged as a patient, they are a real credit, they've helped me so much.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Reddress
title: Contraception services
body: I attended the family planning clinic to have a an IUD fitted. I was feeling very nervous about the procedure. I was greeted by Lesley who welcomed me to the clinic and introduced to the nurse Una who would be performing the procedure. I was not made feel rushed atall even though I was very hesitant and required a bit of reassurance. Both Lesley and Una provided great support throughout the procedure and made me feel as comfortable as I could. In current times there is huge pressure on all clinics and despite this I was not made to feel like I was taking up too much of their time when I felt unwell. A fabulous, supportive team. Thank you for the wonderful experience today.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rel21
title: Fabulous Medical Care
body:
My mum recently had a prolonged stay in RVH. The medical attention she received from Doctors in medical, surgical and ICU teams was amazing, and saved her life. They were also extremely caring in their manner towards my mum and me.  
I had most communication with Dr Phil Wilson and his fabulous team in ward 4B. I would particularly like to thank him for the time he took to phone me over the weeks mum was his patient, as I did not get the opportunity to do this, and it meant a great deal.  
My observation of nursing care on 4B was good. However, the communication from a small minority of nursing staff was abrupt, verging on aggressive and totally unnecessary. Many staff wore no identification.  
Thank you also to the support staff. Unfortunately I can‚Äôt remember all the names, but mum always mentioned Sam who made sure she had plenty of cuppas and had a friendly word.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: piscespn96
title: Falls assessment
body:
My wife rang to see how her Grandmother was getting on following a fall. As this wasn't the first fall she had suffered in the last few months she asked whether a falls assessment had been undertaken, and the reason for her admission. The answer wasn't reassuring as the nurse asked my wife what she meant by this.  
My wife was told that this should have been undertaken as part of her admission but didn't comment on whether this had actually occurred or what had been put in place.  
The trust has a legal responsibility to assess and mitigate to the best of their ability to ensure that a person doesn't come to harm whist in their care. Being told that the "assessment will have been done on admission" offers no assurance that this has actually been undertaken or if undertaken is accurate.  
Falls assessment is rule 101 of elderly admission and should be the precursor to a successful discharge from hospital. I feel like this setting people up to fail, and not ensuring that they are able to fulfil what time they have without fear of unnecessary injury.

author: heyduggee
title: Huge thanks to Ayr Hospital
body:
I had my gallbladder removed yesterday in Day Surgery at Ayr Hospital and wanted to say a HUGE thank you first of all to the lady who pushed my case through to get me in for the surgery.  
I am so happy that I was able to get my surgery on the NHS as this took away intense stress of having to pay private and also the constant anxiety of having attacks when I'm at home with the baby and toddler.  
Treatment was 100 percent perfection yesterday, all staff made me comfortable, explained everything well and clear, extremely friendly friendly chatty and really made me feel at ease. I'm not the easiest patient as have food allergies and my veins are rubbish but nothing was a problem to anyone, I was treated amazingly!  
Thanks to Mr Hussain who done the surgery, you have taken away so much of the pain I had.  
Once again thanks to all the staff that have looked after me whilst I've been in and out of A&E since February with gallbladder pain.  
Special thanks to all the ladies in Station 4 who looked after me when I was admitted back in February.  
I am so grateful to have had this surgery, thank you all so much.

author: matarhh74
title: An elderly patient who was told he was being discharged
body:
It‚Äôs absolutely shocking that we were told 3 days ago that our elderly relative would be discharged, and we were told yesterday that it would be today as they just hadn‚Äôt sorted the discharge out. We‚Äôve waited all day for a call from the Heartlands SAU dept. and it‚Äôs nearly 5. 30pm. If they knew yesterday that they were being discharged today then why have the extra workload of feeding them and them taking a bed up all day?  
We have explained to staff all along that staying in there will affect our relative's mental state, and our relative has made it clear that they want to get out and yet no one seems to be trying to help them with a prompt discharge. There are no medical issues that have risen since yesterday so why all the waiting. Ringing them seems pointless as the telephone just rings out until it is cut off.  
I feel that discharging patients when able should be paramount to their workload?

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: Ebony19
title: Brain Surgery
body:
I have recently had a large olfactory meningioma removed and I am recovering well.  
I can‚Äôt praise The Walton Centre enough .  
Surgery was cancelled from January due to Covid which resulted in me having a major seizure which unfortunately I was in hospital for a few days and eventually had my operation in May. This of course was not the fault of the hospital but due to the pandemic.  
I was admitted to Dott Ward and 24 hours in ITU after my operation . The staff on Dott Ward are amazing from the nurses to the hca and domestics they could not do enough for you the care was exceptional.  
I was so relaxed going into theatre and this was down to the operating team anaesthetist and the nurses so friendly and reassuring .  
ITU doctors and nurses very caring, Vicky my one to one nurse she was amazing I felt so relaxed with her as if I had known her all my life.  
Skull based nurses specialist Chloe and Emma nothing to much trouble for them and always at the end a phone or email for any questions .  
Finally my consultant Mr Yousaf I don‚Äôt use the word hero lightly but I cannot praise him and thank him enough.  
Once again thank you .

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: AD1
title: Misdiagnosis in Cornwall
body:
It is with regret that I feel obliged to write to you. I recently had the misfortune to fall ill while on holiday in Cornwall. I would not wish others to suffer as I did.  
One Tuesday last month at about 8.30 pm I experienced a sudden and extreme abdominal pain. I could not account for this but decided to go and lie down and hope that it passed. I was then violently sick at regular intervals and in extreme pain so I called an ambulance at 3.30 am.  
The ambulance took me to Treliske Hospital where I was examined several times and BP and pulse, etc, checked. My abdomen by this time was hugely extended and very painful. Doctors listened to my abdomen several times.  
After a very uncomfortable night (made bearable by morphine) a doctor came and said that I had Gastritis. A short while later another doctor came and examined me again, including listening to my abdomen. They said that I had a gastric ulcer. They told me to go home and avoid alcohol, fizzy drinks, chocolate and spicy food. To take Gaviscon and painkillers and when I returned home from my holiday to consult my GP about a Gastroscopy.  
My son fetched me home and I followed this advice from Wednesday until Friday. I was extremely nauseous, in considerable pain and ate absolutely nothing. I spent most of my time in bed.  
On Friday I ate a small piece of toast and was immediately sick. I called 111 and was given an appointment at Bodmin Hospital for 9am Saturday morning. I attended this appointment where again I was examined and my abdomen was listened to and declared to be working. No notice was taken of the fact that I said I had not had any motion of the bowel in five days.  
By this time my son was so worried that he insisted that we return home which we did. On Sunday I had to call another ambulance and was taken into Worcester Royal Hospital. Here I was properly examined, x-rayed, scanned and declared to have a bowel blockage and be in urgent need of surgery.  
The consultant surgeon, Mr Wadley, who added me to the end of his already very full operating list on the following Tuesday told me the next morning that my gut was twisted, totally blocked, dead and gangrenous. He said he was glad he had added me on because by morning I would have had peritonitis within ten hours, followed by death. I have since been making a slow recovery.  
My major complaint is that nobody gave a correct diagnosis. Nobody told me that time was of the essence and I needed to get rapid proper attention.  
I understand that this condition is fairly common. I am concerned that patients who present at Treliske or Bodmin with the same symptoms could be given the same misdiagnosis.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Aziz KH
title: Helped my Anxiety
body:
I experienced severe anxiety/panic attack back in December. It resulted in palpitation, agitation, heart sinking feeling, sleeping problems.  
The Informative staff are very knowledgeable and the therapist has been very helpful and encouraging.

author: Avrilm95
title: Covid-19 vaccine
body: Excellent service, quick and painless and the nurse Donal put me at ease and made the experience very simple.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Eckster
title: Colonoscopy
body: Despite recording on my notes that I had experienced severe pain during a previous colonoscopy, I was given a sedative and the consultant proceeded with the colonoscopy which had to be terminated due to acute and severe pain whereby I felt my stomach was about to explode. I have had a number of these previously carried out by specialist nurses who seemed to have the level of pain relief spot on and managed to conduct a full investigation without too much difficulty. I was slightly perturbed by the consultant‚Äôs jovial pre procedure warning against whinging in the room during the procedure. This may have been an attempt to lighten the mood prior to my colonoscopy but has now left me feeling that this failed attempt is somehow my fault and, although I normally have a high pain threshold, this morning was totally unbearable.

readBy.name: Office of Annabelle Ewing, MSP for Cowdenbeath

author: Derp
title: Gynaecology
body:
Due to smear test showing high risk cells and cell changes I had to come in for a colposcopy.  
Both Dr Kumar and the nurse, Nikki, were really friendly and explained everything that was going to happen and what was going to happen next.  
Caring, friendly and made everything go easily, even though the procedure itself wasn't a comfortable thing.

author: mitzy002
title: Get all the support needed to manage my diabetes
body: I spoke to my gp on the Wednesday and was referred to the community diabetes specialist nurse clinic and I got a call from them the next day. The nurse explained the next steps to me & that I would be sent a near me appt. She gave me details about what I needed to do before my appointment and made everything very clear to me. I was surprised at how quick they made contact and that day I got an appointment through for the following Wednesday so only a week between referral & my appointment. Impressed with the short wait as normally waiting times are long. Also like that they refer you to the dietician too as standard so get all the support needed to manage your diabetes. Nurse was very helpful and pleasant to talk to.

title: Impossible to contact; unhelpful on urgent issues
body: I needed an urgent prescription. I emailed, with no response. Getting through on the phone took over an hour all told: not because of waiting times, but because my call was cut off over 10 times. When I finally got through, they were not helpful: urgent - how about waiting 5 days? "I'll talk to a GP about it and you'll get a text." Instead, no text and another hour wait on the phone.

title: Extremely Incompetent Doctors
body: This pathetic excuse of a GP Centre can not even provide appointments for weeks or even answer their phone. Drs here are useless and its more of a family business than anything.

author: Conor100
title: Virtual visit lifts the spirits in Hospital and home
body: Nana had been very ill earlier this week causing all family members to be very concerned. Thankfully and as a result of the care and attention of the medical staff at CAH, she has turned a corner and is on the mend again. With the COVID restrictions still in place it is difficult for the family and Nana as visiting is limited. Our virtual visit this evening proved a great tonic for everyone as we were able to see the improvement in Nana and she was able to see how much we were willing her well again. Thanks to all involved for facilitating this service as it has proved invaluable in lifting both Nana‚Äôs and the families spirits at this difficult time.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: DC77
title: CT scan
body: I had to have a CT scan today at the Blue Sky Imaging Suite. I was worried about having a cannula put in due to a previous bad experience (not at this department). The nurse who did it was really kind and got it on the first attempt. The rest of the procedure was explained as it was done and I left feeling that this had been a positive experience.

readBy.name: Northern Lincolnshire and Goole NHS Foundation Trust

author: authenticwk43
title: Knee surgery
body:
I was admitted in May at 07.30 am. The day and evening staff and docs gave me was 100%, and I can't thank them enough. I was in a lot off pain and at night with the night staff I feel this changed. I had not been walking due to the level of pain I was under this day , and was advised I would be starting the next day. So through the night I was assisted to the ladies using a wheeled commode , and I used my walker for help as I was given this for transferring only not walking at this time. I had a night shift staff member assist me but they did not show as much empathy as the others.  
Myself I have work in the care sector for 16 years but the past 3 I have worked in rehabilitation so I had the understanding of what happened.  
So after I went to the toilet, where I was left to try and help myself, I was then taken back to my bed , where I pushed through my pain levels to get back into the bed. this nurse took to chair away and then walked away, I was left to wash my hands with a wipe and to get my legs back into bed myself. I did not have a good sleep as there was other people in pain which I was fully understand. I just feel that this nurse was not the most helpful person, for me that night . Once I was in bed then the curtains was closed.  
Today when I felt I spoke to a lovely staff member that was in the day of my operation and she said I looked much better than the day of my operation, I explained what I felt and I was then given this card and I explained to the staff member I worked in the care sector, and she said so you know what to expect.  
Out off all the staff it was that one I did not feel comfortable with. I got the feeling it was like lets get the job done quick .  
The physios were also amazing towards me and the Drs also, Dr cook was lovely towards me after my operation he even came up after his last operation to make sure my pain level was under control as it took about 4 hours to settle this. The anps were also amazing with my care, can't thank them enough.  
But over all I only had the 1 thing wrong. Which I hope this can be fixed.

readBy.name: Office of Annabelle Ewing, MSP for Cowdenbeath

author: Ivan Grozny
title: Treatment for skin cancer
body: After my GP unaccountably told me to come back in a month when I showed him what turned out to be a squamous cell cancer ("nothing to worry about") I got referred to the local NHS Hospital at Treliske in Cornwall. By the then the lesion was quite large. They quickly set up a surgical excision which went really well and two weeks later the cancer has gone, though I will need some radiotherapy to reduce the risk of reocurrence. All the staff in dermatology were great, the surgeon was brilliant, they were swift, efficient and effective. I couldn't fault the treatment and I am amazed they can achieve this at a difficult time for the NHS.

author: Eck567
title: How smoothly both my covid vaccines went
body:
Just wanted to say how well I was treated and how smoothly both my covid vaccines went. Staff were so friendly and well organised, there was no waiting around. Was made to feel relaxed and the centre was clean and safe.  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']  
[Very happy with 'Waiting time']  
[Very happy with 'Cleanliness']

author: Tompicking
title: My wonderful Dad in Ward 3B
body:
My wonderful Dad Tommy spent the last 4 weeks of his life being cared for in Ward 3B of the Ulster hospital.  
My Dad was admitted after visiting his doctor with a shortness of breath and immediately received oxygen and antibiotics to fight an infection in his lungs, which we later found out was pneumonia.  
From the day he was admitted he was so thankful of the care and respectful attention he received and for 3 weeks believed he was a fraud and kept telling the staff that he was sorry for bothering them. He loved the food so much that we called his stay in the ward, his Spa retreat.  
Sadly and after a very brave battle, Tommy, my Dad, my mentor, my friend and wonderful husband to my Mum, fantastic father in law to my wife, and legendary Granda to our children, passed away on Friday 28th May 2021.  
On behalf of my Father and our family I just want to express my sincere gratitude to everyone who cared for him, from the cleaning and catering staff to the nurses and doctors who treated him with dignity and respect throughout his illness.  
I will always be indebted to you for looking after such a special person in my life and I am comforted knowing that he passed away with us at his bedside, fully aware of how much he meant to us and how loved he was.  
Thank you all for taking care of him and for allowing us to visit when we needed to, without exception. The staff we encountered in Ward 3B of the Ulster Hospital are legendary, just like my Dad and the family thank you for everything you all did.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: CountryGirl92
title: Vaccine & Needle Phobia
body: Every single member of staff guided me every step of the way, constantly reassured me and never rushed me- even when I was in floods of irrational tears. I had my jab in a secluded cubicle and was able to lie down and have two nurses beside me who talked me through the whole ‚Äòquick prick‚Äô. I was never made to feel silly or a time waster. Thank you everyone. X

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shimi
title: Great and very professional
body:
I had appointment at Gynaecology department and went through the operation Hysteroscopy.  
Staff were great and very professional.u feel much better now.  
Big thank you to everyone there.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: AmericaninBelfast
title: COVID-19 Vaccine
body: I went for my first dose and every single person was cheerful, helpful, and quick to tell me where I needed to go etc. It was so smooth and ran so well - great job NHS staff! They answered my few questions and the vaccine took seconds and was painless. You guys are wonderful! Thank you for all you do!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: decemberqr64
title: Son with swollen wrist and in pain
body:
Contacted minor injuries in Downe Hospital and got a prompt appointment. Service was quick and staff were very efficient and caring towards my son.  
Son had to get a cast for wrist.  
In and out in 45mins.  
Unfortunate result for son but fortunate that we received our care in Downe Hospital.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: StagPixie
title: Coil change after 6 years
body: Had the old one out and new one in. Felt anxious but the staff were lovely.

author: Loanhead 17
title: Hospital at Home
body:
The Hospital at Home Team is a service for acutely ill medical patients, providing care in the patient's own home as an alternative to hospital admission.  
I am the main carer for my elderly mother and we have had to use the services of Hospital at Home on several occasions in the past year.  
The care shown by all the visiting staff is truly first class. They have looked after mum with care and compassion, they have listened to what we had to say about mum's care and her ongoing health issues and the team kept us informed at all times as to what they thought were appropriate interventions.  
As well as dealing with mum's immediate health issues the Hospital at Home Team also took the time to consider and review mum's ongoing care. Again they listened to her family, discussed historical health issues and put in place actions for mum's future care.  
Although we are always anxious when mum is unwell we were always reassured when Hospital at Home are involved in her care.  
Thank you Hospital at Home Team!  
In my opinion Hospital at Home is a service that should be made more widely available across the NHS. Skilled professionals working in a small, dynamic team can only enhance the care system. The service allows patients the opportunity to be in their own home, hopefully with their loved ones, reducing some of the stress and anxiety while being acutely ill.

author: izarbp73
title: Coil fitting
body: Very well looked after, Dr Kundu and the nurse made me feel at ease and I had nothing to worry about.

author: Ryusan12
title: STI check up
body: Spoke to a nurse and got tested for STIs. Service and overall experience were excellent.

author: severityrt66
title: 1st COVID vaccine - well oiled machine
body: On arrival I was extremely nervous and started crying when I saw the nurse. She was the loveliest lady and completely reassuring. The jab was over before I knew it and pain free. Fantastic staff from the man on the car park entrance gate, to the ladies at the 15 min waiting area. The vaccine centre runs like a well oiled machine.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Red85gla
title: My son's broken arm
body:
I would like to say a huge thank you to all staff at the Royal Children's Hospital in Glasgow. My 7 year old son broke his arm and had to get pins put in. From the moment we arrived to the moment we left we were taken care of and felt very safe and welcome. The staff were amazing and so friendly and absolutely brilliant with kids. Special thank you to Lyndsay, Kim, Rachel, Michael and Alana. They really know how to put kids at ease. Michael the anesthetist was brilliant and chatted away to him and made him laugh just before he was put to sleep. We had a lovely private room in ward 3c and it felt like a hotel. We got brought a lovely lunch (the best homemade soup) and dinner, which was unexpected, and we kept getting asked if we wanted a tea or coffee. My son was desperate for cereal after his surgery at 2.30pm and they brought it happily. The room was immaculate and cleaned constantly. We were given an aftercare plan and Alana talked through it all clearly before we left and she was happy to answer any questions.  
My son said it was such a fun hospital and even said it was awesome ü•∞. Thank you once again!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: paprikaww88
title: My journey at hopewood
body:
Isolation was tricky but eating in separate rooms and the tv was a good idea and a good distraction.  
Letting us have choices over cereals and supper was really nice and we the chance to have something we like.  
Playing on the wii was a really good distraction but changing the time to the same time as leisure group isn‚Äôt good for people who do the group and would be better at a different time.  
Distractions in the dining room like quizzes helped.  
More bigger sensory toys in the relaxation room would help to.  
Going on walks with staff on grounds and local are leave are really nice too.

author: Anne321
title: Kind and reassuring staff during my covid vaccine
body: I went to the vaccination centre feeling scared and extremely anxious. From the moment I walked in the staff were so kind caring and professional. Having a phobia of needles, I was terrified. The staff talked me through the process, gave me a recliner chair and a private area to sit. Tracy was wonderful and I didn't even notice I had the vaccine done! Thank you for your professionalism, patience and kindness. If you are nervous, don't worry you are in safe hands. See you in August!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: octoberxn67
title: My experience of Ward 205
body: I've been a patient of this ward for over 5 years and along with carefully and professional managing the ward, Katie, Jen and Kay also dispense daily medications to patients along with the help of Lisa, Fiona, Marri, Connie, Laura, Elsie, Marta, Brian, Elliot and Sam to name a few, they also perform routine nursing duties with the help of Eric, Erin, Lauren A and Lauren M. The ward is kept functioning with the help of Eileen, Louise, Jane and Helen keeping all topped up with tea and biscuits, all kept spottlesly clean by Ross.

author: muscasd55
title: COVID-19 Vaccine
body: It was very quick and efficient, organised very well. The nurse who administered mine was lovely, made sure I was comfortable with needles and reassured me when receiving the vaccine.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: omegadn49
title: partial deafness
body:
I have lost 50% of my hearing in both ears and was referred to Audio nhs in Truro.  
I received excellent ,clear and caring attention and precise instruction after care VIVA N.H.S.

author: Lorfp47
title: my husband
body:
My husband was taken into Ninewells about 5 weeks ago, he had a really bad cough and had lost a lot of weight. Covid was ruled out as he had presented other symptoms, and he was moved to ICU. This was a terribly difficult time for me as, one, I am waiting for a hip replacement at another hospital ( about 100 miles away) and we have no family so visiting was down to me alone. I cannot thank the staff enough, the receptionists who got to know my face, the porters for wheeling me down to the ward and the many nurses and doctors who, apart from doing their own tasks, took time out to speak to me and to help me understand what was happening.  
My husband was very ill and I believe he had been given CPR several times. I am now waiting to find out when he is going to the High Dependancy Unit. To see your loved one is a state of sedation with ventilation is horrible and to see them so helpless when they come round is equally so.  
Many many thanks to all the staff as mentioned above. Without their support I think I would not have coped nearly so well.

author: AMagee
title: Brilliant care at Antrim ED Minors nurse practitioners
body: My 5 year old son fell and broke his arm on Saturday, we went straight to Minors, Sheelagh ENP seen him straight away, X-ray organised promptly and Senior doc review shortly after. I am so grateful to Sheelagh, Beth, Damian, Paula & Kate for being so patient, kind and using distraction technique‚Äôs to help my boy to be pain free prior to plaster application. We received first class care from a fab team in Antrim ED. Thank you! !

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: paparg45
title: My eating disorder
body:
Back in 2017 I found myself struggling with an eating disorder that was the result of a running injury and my own desire to achieve what I perceived to be a ‚Äòperfect‚Äô figure. Unfortunately my eating disorder spiralled really very quickly and I was hospitalised in July 2018 as I became very unwell. The team at Barnsley Hospital recognised I needed inpatient support and were able to get me an inpatient bed at Riverdale Grange.  
Eating disorders are so misunderstood. Nothing frustrates me more than the DSM-5 criteria as I was struggling with anorexia and disordered eating way before my BMI dropped to a dangerously low level. I was rejected by my GP on several occasions for treatment, and not considered a priority for referral to psychiatric services as my behaviours weren‚Äôt considered destructive enough. So naturally I put myself on a warpath after that to prove I was sick enough to deserve treatment. Still I am very grateful for the ANP at my surgery who was quick to admit me after a routine check up - they showed the most understanding of anyone to that point, let me cry it out in the surgery with them and then helped me into a taxi to Barnsley Hospital.  
I am thrilled to say I am now in a very good place with my eating disorder which must be attributed to the efforts of the staff at Riverdale Grange and my own determination.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Great experiences
body: Can't fault the experiences I've had since moving to this doctors. The doctor is very patient and listens carefully, showing concern at all times. They also have a good sense of humour which helps and are great with my son when I take him. I've only once not been able to get through in the morning to get an appointment the same day, and since the pandemic started the process of having an initial telephone consultation has worked well. Would definitely recommend this practice.

title: Appointment availabilty
body: I can't get through on the phone in time to make an appointment, I can't make an appointment online, as they're only doing smears. was told to call 111 . I NEED to get on HRT and NO-ONE can help

author: Ellsr87
title: Thank you to all involved.
body:
I was admitted to the SATA unit in the early hours of Thursday morning, with a positive covid test, and poor oxygen saturation, and have been in here on oxygen for the past 4 days.  
The care I have received has been absolutely first class - everyone from the paramedics who brought me in, the porters who took me too and from x-ray, the doctors and the ward staff have been amazing - friendly, very informative, supportive, and caring - I couldn‚Äôt ask for better.  
The food has been good - not that I can taste it, but it is hot and well presented, and seems well made - and appears to be cooked from scratch, with care and attention - just what a poorly patient needs - good, nutritious, tasty (when you have a sense of taste - lol) food!  
Thank you to all involved.

author: SmileyK91
title: First vaccine
body: I got my first vaccine today at the SSE arena in Belfast. I am sorry I did not get my nurses name but she was very nice and helpful. I am nervous about needles so she distracted me very well and was very chatty. The staff were friendly and organised. Everything was well laid out and I was taken early which was great! Thanks to all the staff working at SSE you are doing a great job to help us all!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: olifreeman
title: You saved our mums life
body:
Our mum was rushed to A&E at Queens Medical Centre, Nottingham in May with a strangulated hernia. On Friday, we were told that she was to undergo very risky major surgery to resolve the strangulation - the odds of her pulling through from this weren't fantastic due to pre-existing conditions and the severity of her situation, but if she didn't have this surgery, she would've definitely died.  
Our mum was operated on by Dr. Parsons, who seems to have worked an absolute miracle on her, as she is recovering really well as we speak after spending a number of days in ICU at QMC, as well as other wards.  
To all of the staff involved in her treatment and recovery, we cannot thank you enough You really have saved her life, and for that, we are eternally grateful. We couldn't be luckier to have such a fantastic NHS provider and such fantastic and amazing doctors and nurses so close to our doorstep.  
Thank you, so much.

author: Mamakate
title: Miscarriage
body:
I am shocked at just how poor miscarriage care was in my hospital. It was a very "cold", matter of fact experience and I didn't feel very supported or cared for at all going through one of the hardest things in my life. I wasn't given any leaflets or information and had no follow up.  
When I asked if I would get early scans if I was pregnant again the midwives said that the Consultant is quite strict and that unless I had had recurrent miscarriages or was in pain and bleeding they wouldn't be allowed to see me early in a new pregnancy. I was very upset at this. It felt so dismissive and lacking in compassion, especially when I had just lost my baby. I naturally thought I'd get more appointments and scans next time.  
EPU staff in the Belfast Trust don't seem to have a good understanding of what their patients who miscarry are going through. I wasn't even offered a chat with the bereavement midwife in the Trust- who is this service there for then?  
The Belfast Trust really need to look at how they treat people who have miscarriages. I was very upset at the attitude and lack of emotional care. You really wouldn't have thought I had lost a baby the way they got on. I know miscarriage is common and they see it every day but it is still really upsetting and that was my baby. I have read about people having a better experience in some other hospitals. The Royal Maternity miscarriage bit need to make big changes- I was shocked because I'd had a baby there before and the way I was treated was good.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences
